values.description:
As discussed [in this thread](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/pull-requests/276/logging-part-8-ignition-tools-ign-log/activity#comment-62231607), the API of the `Playback` class may be misleading.

This PR refactors the functionality of `Playback` into `Playback` and `PlaybackHandle`. This is advantageous because:

1. It makes the control flow of playing back logs much more explicit
2. It reduces the number of potential errors or misuse that we need to handle

However, there are currently two disadvantages:

1. The log file is getting opened twice: once while setting up the playback, and a second time while starting the playback. This can probably be fixed with some adjustments to `raii_sqlite3`, so input from @sloretz would be very valuable for this. (Basically: can we get a lazy copy of the sqlite3 database, preferably without reopening the log file?)
2. The user becomes responsible for holding onto the `PlaybackHandlePtr` that gets returned by `Playback::Start()`. This is similar to the user's responsibility over `Node::Publisher`s, so I don't see this as a significant disadvantage.
values.title: Refactor Playback into Playback and PlaybackHandle

summary.raw:
As discussed [in this thread](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/pull-requests/276/logging-part-8-ignition-tools-ign-log/activity#comment-62231607), the API of the `Playback` class may be misleading.

This PR refactors the functionality of `Playback` into `Playback` and `PlaybackHandle`. This is advantageous because:

1. It makes the control flow of playing back logs much more explicit
2. It reduces the number of potential errors or misuse that we need to handle

However, there are currently two disadvantages:

1. The log file is getting opened twice: once while setting up the playback, and a second time while starting the playback. This can probably be fixed with some adjustments to `raii_sqlite3`, so input from @sloretz would be very valuable for this. (Basically: can we get a lazy copy of the sqlite3 database, preferably without reopening the log file?)
2. The user becomes responsible for holding onto the `PlaybackHandlePtr` that gets returned by `Playback::Start()`. This is similar to the user's responsibility over `Node::Publisher`s, so I don't see this as a significant disadvantage.
summary.html:
As discussed in this thread, the API of the Playback class may be misleading.

This PR refactors the functionality of Playback into Playback and PlaybackHandle. This is advantageous because:

  1. It makes the control flow of playing back logs much more explicit
  2. It reduces the number of potential errors or misuse that we need to handle

However, there are currently two disadvantages:

  1. The log file is getting opened twice: once while setting up the playback, and a second time while starting the playback. This can probably be fixed with some adjustments to raii_sqlite3, so input from @sloretz would be very valuable for this. (Basically: can we get a lazy copy of the sqlite3 database, preferably without reopening the log file?)
  2. The user becomes responsible for holding onto the PlaybackHandlePtr that gets returned by Playback::Start(). This is similar to the user's responsibility over Node::Publishers, so I don't see this as a significant disadvantage.

values.description:
When we switched to `ign-cmake1`, we forgot about the example programs in the log directory.

This is a quick fix so that the examples can be compiled as a separate cmake project. In the long run, I believe our goal is to clean up the root `example` folder and then move the log examples into the root `example` folder, but this should help keep the log examples functional until we have time to clean up the root examples.
values.title: Quick fix so that log examples work again

summary.raw:

summary.html:
When we switched to ign-cmake1, we forgot about the example programs in the log directory.

This is a quick fix so that the examples can be compiled as a separate cmake project. values.description:
See issue #89.

The idea behind this pull request is to detect the SIOCGIFINDEX associated to each network interface. If we detect a repeated SIOCGIFINDEX, we assume is a subinterface and do not include it in the list of interfaces returned by `determineInterfaces()`.
values.title: Fix issue #89

summary.raw:
See issue #89.

The idea behind this pull request is to detect the SIOCGIFINDEX associated to each network interface. If we detect a repeated SIOCGIFINDEX, we assume is a subinterface and do not include it in the list of interfaces returned by `determineInterfaces()`.
summary.html:
See issue #89.

The idea behind this pull request is to detect the SIOCGIFINDEX associated to each network interface. If we detect a repeated SIOCGIFINDEX, we assume is a subinterface and do not include it in the list of interfaces returned by determineInterfaces().

values.description:
This fixes a possible cause of #90. This is the only place I could find where an `std::function`is used without checking if it is valid. In ignition transport 4 the `Record` class doesn't set the disconnection callback on the discovery class. If this particular call to the callback happens then `std::bad_function_call` would be thrown.

I didn't write a unit test. I’m happy to write one, but the conditions this could happen are very specific: 

1. Something needs to instantiate the Discovery class and not set a disconnection callback on it
2. Next the Discovery instance must get a discovery message from a publisher which doesn’t send another message for more than 3 seconds
3. Finally the discovery instance must receive a message from a different publisher, which triggers this particular call to the disconnection callback

‌
values.title: Check callback is valid before calling it

If this particular call to the callback happens then `std::bad_function_call` would be thrown.

I didn't write a unit test. I’m happy to write one, but the conditions this could happen are very specific: 

1. Something needs to instantiate the Discovery class and not set a disconnection callback on it
2. Next the Discovery instance must get a discovery message from a publisher which doesn’t send another message for more than 3 seconds
3. Finally the discovery instance must receive a message from a different publisher, which triggers this particular call to the disconnection callback

summary.html:
This fixes a possible cause of #90. This is the only place I could find where an std::functionis used without checking if it is valid. In ignition transport 4 the Record class doesn't set the disconnection callback on the discovery class. If this particular call to the callback happens then std::bad_function_call would be thrown.

I didn't write a unit test. I’m happy to write one, but the conditions this could happen are very specific:

  1. Something needs to instantiate the Discovery class and not set a disconnection callback on it
  2. Next the Discovery instance must get a discovery message from a publisher which doesn’t send another message for more than 3 seconds
  3. Finally the discovery instance must receive a message from a different publisher, which triggers this particular call to the disconnection callback

values.description:
This PR extends ign log playback for supporting topic remapping. The use case here is to playback a topic name with a different name than the one originally used during the recording phase. I feel that this is the only ign command so far, in which makes sense to implement topic remapping but let me know if you think that we should add support for other commands too.

*~~Note: Depends on pull request #330, which should be merged first.~~*
values.title: Support topic remapping - 2/3 ign support

summary.raw:
This PR extends ign log playback for supporting topic remapping. The use case here is to playback a topic name with a different name than the one originally used during the recording phase. I feel that this is the only ign command so far, in which makes sense to implement topic remapping but let me know if you think that we should add support for other commands too.

*~~Note: Depends on pull request #330, which should be merged first.~~*
summary.html:
This PR extends ign log playback for supporting topic remapping. The use case here is to playback a topic name with a different name than the one originally used during the recording phase. I feel that this is the only ign command so far, in which makes sense to implement topic remapping but let me know if you think that we should add support for other commands too.

Note: Depends on pull request #330, which should be merged first.

values.description:
This PR adds:

* The `Step` feature to the `Playback` class
* The integration test for it

The internal structure of the Implementation class has been slightly restructured in order to pave the way for the next feature to be implemented: `Seek`.

* Both the `Batch` and its iterator are now owned by the Implementation class, and generated at the moment of the creation of the object \(no need to `std::move`them\).
values.title: Step playback

summary.raw:
This PR adds:

* The `Step` feature to the `Playback` class
* The integration test for it

The internal structure of the Implementation class has been slightly restructured in order to pave the way for the next feature to be implemented: `Seek`.

* Both the `Batch` and its iterator are now owned by the Implementation class, and generated at the moment of the creation of the object \(no need to `std::move`them\).
summary.html:
This PR adds:

  • The Step feature to the Playback class
  • The integration test for it

The internal structure of the Implementation class has been slightly restructured in order to pave the way for the next feature to be implemented: Seek.

  • Both the Batch and its iterator are now owned by the Implementation class, and generated at the moment of the creation of the object (no need to std::movethem).

values.description: This pull request introduces a `Clock` abstraction to seamlessly use different time sources. As of the time of writing, either OS time or a topic-based clock can be used. This abstraction is then leveraged to enable the \`log::Recorder\` to use a simulated time when timestamp'ing messages.
values.title: Adds alternative clock support to the log::Recorder class

summary.raw: This pull request introduces a `Clock` abstraction to seamlessly use different time sources. As of the time of writing, either OS time or a topic-based clock can be used. This abstraction is then leveraged to enable the \`log::Recorder\` to use a simulated time when timestamp'ing messages.
summary.html: This pull request introduces a Clock abstraction to seamlessly use different time sources. As of the time of writing, either OS time or a topic-based clock can be used. This abstraction is then leveraged to enable the `log::Recorder` to use a simulated time when timestamp'ing messages.

values.description: This pull request exposes additional playback status: namely `StartTime()`, `EndTime()` and `CurrentTime()` methods in the `log::PlaybackHandle` class. To this end, the `log::Log` class has been extended to query the database for this information.

values.description:
We have a problem when working on Windows with the length of paths \(restricted to 200 chars\). While testing ign-gui on Windows I faced problems with the nice long names that we use in the test suite.

This PR replaces Preocesses by Procs and Increasing by Inc. I hope that the changes are not too hard to kill the readability of tests.
values.title: Make test names shorter to avoid problems on Windows cmd

summary.raw:
We have a problem when working on Windows with the length of paths \(restricted to 200 chars\). While testing ign-gui on Windows I faced problems with the nice long names that we use in the test suite.

This PR replaces Preocesses by Procs and Increasing by Inc. I hope that the changes are not too hard to kill the readability of tests.
summary.html:
We have a problem when working on Windows with the length of paths (restricted to 200 chars). While testing ign-gui on Windows I faced problems with the nice long names that we use in the test suite.

This PR replaces Preocesses by Procs and Increasing by Inc. I hope that the changes are not too hard to kill the readability of tests.

values.description:
I noticed there were only a few windows compiler warnings on the `gz11` branch, and they were related to the Clock class:

* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=ignition_transport-ci-gz11-windows7-amd64&build=5)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_transport-ci-gz11-windows7-amd64/5/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/BuildCopFail/job/ignition_transport-ci-gz11-windows7-amd64/5/warnings43Result/

These warnings are also present on `default`, so I'm fixing them here so they can be merged forward.
values.title: fix Clock compiler warnings on windows

summary.raw:
I noticed there were only a few windows compiler warnings on the `gz11` branch, and they were related to the Clock class:

* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=ignition_transport-ci-gz11-windows7-amd64&build=5)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_transport-ci-gz11-windows7-amd64/5/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/BuildCopFail/job/ignition_transport-ci-gz11-windows7-amd64/5/warnings43Result/

These warnings are also present on `default`, so I'm fixing them here so they can be merged forward.
summary.html:
I noticed there were only a few windows compiler warnings on the gz11 branch, and they were related to the Clock class:

  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/BuildCopFail/job/ignition_transport-ci-gz11-windows7-amd64/5/warnings43Result/

These warnings are also present on default, so I'm fixing them here so they can be merged forward.
